conversation.content: Good afternoon. I need to discuss a... what's the word... a chargeback. Filed against me.
Alright so—let me just—I can definitely help you with that today, um, could I get your merchant account number to pull up the details?
MER-7294. Private chef services.

Perfect, um, so I'm seeing account MER-7294-PC here and, uh, there's a dispute filed yesterday for, hmm, let me see... transaction TXN-829461-QV for three thousand eight hundred dollars, is that the one we're looking at?
So basically, um, this client—she ate the entire dinner. Five courses. Then files this.

I understand—no wait, let me—okay so I can see here that the dispute reason code is RRC-03, which is, um, "services not as described" and unfortunately that's one where we need documentation from your side.
How do I know you're not just... protecting them? The wealthy ones?

So, um, I get why you'd think that but, uh, actually the process is pretty standard regardless of the amount, and, hmm, what I can do is walk you through exactly what evidence packet EPK-7294-01 needs to include.
Evidence. For food. That's been eaten.

Right so—actually let me—the thing is, um, for catering disputes we typically need, uh, signed contracts, photos if you have them, and any communication with the client, reference number DOC-SET-94A covers all that.
Um, so like, I have texts where she's, uh, praising everything. During the dinner.
That's perfect actually, those text messages can be uploaded to case file CSE-829461-A, and, um, if she's specifically mentioning satisfaction with the service, that's really strong evidence.
She said "divine." Her word. Divine.
Excellent, so—wait actually—make sure when you submit those through portal link PTL-7294.disputes.com, um, you include timestamps and, uh, the full conversation thread, not just selected messages.
So basically what you're, um, telling me is... I have to prove I cooked food. That she ate.
I know it's—look, I've seen these before and, um, with proper documentation, especially those texts, dispute reversal rate is about, uh, seventy-eight percent in code RRV-78-FOOD cases like yours.
Seventy-eight. So one in four, I just... lose. Despite doing everything right.

Unfortunately that's—I mean—the bank makes final call on case ARB-829461, but, um, what I can do is flag this for expedited review, should have an initial response within, uh, three business days instead of the usual seven.
Um, how do I know that's actually, like, expedited? Or just... what you tell everyone?

So your expedite code is EXP-7294-11A and, um, you'll get an automated email from notify@disputes-MER.com confirming that status, uh, usually within the next hour, and that's system-generated, not something I control.

scenario: private chef, dealing with a wealthy client who filed a credit card dispute against her
